data: Dedication to the Genius of the city of Catania

A tablet of white marble, smooth on the sides and the
                                            reverse, with the remains of a raised border (a moulding?) on the right
                                            side. The front face is lightly convex.

The text is preserved intact, over seven lines, although the edge
                                        of the surviving stone clips the tops of the letters of the first line. The
                                        letters diminish in size over the first four lines, with a vacat in the second
                                        half of line four; the final three lines are larger again. The left margin of
                                        the text is maintained regularly, the right margin varies from line to line.

The letters are deeply but somewhat irregularly cut, with some
                                    internal variation (e.g. A appears with both broken and straight bar; E appears both
                                    as a tall narrow standard E and as a vertical stroke with a single horizontal bar
                                    across the middle; V appears both as V and as Y). Interpuncts are mostly absent,
                                    except after VC and CONS in the final two lines.
Found 18 May 1770 in excavations in the ancient theatre of Catania, by the Principe di Biscari
Photograph of front face by J. Prag
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae

“L’année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l’antiquité romaine.,” L’année épigraphique : revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l’antiquité romaine., 1888, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/630058599

K. Korhonen, Le Iscrizioni Del Museo Civico Di Catania : Storia Delle Collezioni, Cultura Epigrafica, Edizione (Helsinki: Societas Scientiarum Fennica, 2004)

Giacomo Manganaro, “Iscrizioni Latine e Greche Di Catania Tardo-Imperiale,” Archivio Storico per La Sicilia Orientale ser.4 vol.11-12 (1959 1958): 5–30

R.J.A. Wilson, Sicily under the Roman Empire: The Archaeology of a Roman Province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535 (Warminster: Aris and Philips, 1990)
Greco nei pagi e latino nelle città della Sicilia romana tra I e VI sec. d.C.
Giacomo Manganaro, “Greco nei pagi e latino nelle città della Sicilia romana tra I e VI sec. d.C.,” in l’epigrafia del villaggio, ed. A. Calbi, A. Donati, and G. Poma (Faenza, 1993), 543–94

standardisation of template and tidying up encoding

Munatidius is not otherwise known; the mention of three Domini
                                    requires one of the periods 337—340, 367—378, 379—383, 388—395, 402—408, and 421. A
                                    precise choice is not possible, but the consensus amongst scholars is for a date in
                                    the 4th century rather than later.

Vernantibus
                    saeculis  
                    
                    Genio splendidae ur
                    bis 
                    
                     
                    
                    
                    
                     eiusdem

At the dawn of the new age of our threefold lordship, (dedicated) to the Genius of the splendid city
                    of Catania. Facundus Porfyrius Mynatidius, vir clarissimus, consular governor of the same (city?)
                    (set this up).

Nel rifiorire dell'era dei nostri tre signori, al genio della splendida città di Catania Facundio
                    Porfirio Munatidio, senatore (vir clarissimus) governatore consolare della stessa (città?) (dedicò).

The text (on imported marble) would have been fixed to the base of a statue of the Genius of the city
                    of Catania, probably erected on the stage-building of the theatre. The Genius was the protective
                    spirit of a person or a thing. Dedications to the Genius of the Emperor were common, but also to
                    cities (e.g. both a statue and temple of the Genius of the city of Lilybaeum = Marsala are mentioned
                    in other inscriptions). Facundus Porfyrius is not otherwise known. The precise significance of 'cons
                    eiusdem' in line 7 is extensively debated and several alternatives have been suggested: the most
                    likely interpretation is 'consularis eiusdem', signifying consularis of the same city, i.e. Catania,
                    and so by extension / implication the province of Sicily.
ISic000298. Dedication to the Genius of the city of Catania

Facsimile Images

1VERNANTIBUS
2SAECULISDN
3GENIOSPLENDIDAEUR
4BISCATINAE
5FACUNDUSPORFYRIUS
6MYNATIDIUSVC
7CONSEIUSDEM

Apparatus criticus

English translation

At the dawn of the new age of our threefold lordship, (dedicated) to the Genius of the splendid city of Catania. Facundus Porfyrius Mynatidius, vir clarissimus, consular governor of the same (city?) (set this up).

Italian translation

Nel rifiorire dell'era dei nostri tre signori, al genio della splendida città di Catania Facundio Porfirio Munatidio, senatore (vir clarissimus) governatore consolare della stessa (città?) (dedicò).

commentary

The text (on imported marble) would have been fixed to the base of a statue of the Genius of the city of Catania, probably erected on the stage-building of the theatre. The Genius was the protective spirit of a person or a thing. Dedications to the Genius of the Emperor were common, but also to cities (e.g. both a statue and temple of the Genius of the city of Lilybaeum = Marsala are mentioned in other inscriptions). Facundus Porfyrius is not otherwise known. The precise significance of 'cons eiusdem' in line 7 is extensively debated and several alternatives have been suggested: the most likely interpretation is 'consularis eiusdem', signifying consularis of the same city, i.e. Catania, and so by extension / implication the province of Sicily.

English translation

At the dawn of the new age of our threefold lordship, (dedicated) to the Genius of the splendid city of Catania. Facundus Porfyrius Mynatidius, vir clarissimus, consular governor of the same (city?) (set this up).

Italian translation

Nel rifiorire dell'era dei nostri tre signori, al genio della splendida città di Catania Facundio Porfirio Munatidio, senatore (vir clarissimus) governatore consolare della stessa (città?) (dedicò).

commentary

The text (on imported marble) would have been fixed to the base of a statue of the Genius of the city of Catania, probably erected on the stage-building of the theatre. The Genius was the protective spirit of a person or a thing. Dedications to the Genius of the Emperor were common, but also to cities (e.g. both a statue and temple of the Genius of the city of Lilybaeum = Marsala are mentioned in other inscriptions). Facundus Porfyrius is not otherwise known. The precise significance of 'cons eiusdem' in line 7 is extensively debated and several alternatives have been suggested: the most likely interpretation is 'consularis eiusdem', signifying consularis of the same city, i.e. Catania, and so by extension / implication the province of Sicily.
